newsitem.title: USA: Wall Street stocks seen softer at open.
newsitem.headline: Wall Street stocks seen softer at open.

text.p: U.S. stocks were expected to open weaker on Monday, burdened by continued profit-taking in the tech sector and wary ahead of quarterly results from International Business Machines Corp and a speech Tuesday by Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan.

"We're probably going to open easier," Larry Wachtel, an analyst at Prudential Securities said. "The Greenspan appearance tomorrow and the IBM results after the close will hold back any kind of a snap-back. We should be on the defensive for most of the day."

Greenspan will make a semi-annual testimony to the House Banking Subcommittee on Tuesday. Markets would pay close attention to anything the Fed chairman said about interest rates or inflation, analysts said.

IBM, which shrugged off Friday's declines in the technology sector to finish higher, was set to report second quarter earnings after the market close. The First Call consensus estimate was $1.42 per share compared to $1.26 per share in the year-ago quarter.
The Standard & Poor's 500 futures index was up one point at 918. The long bond was unchanged at a 6.53 percent yield.
